contextId.information: Sitting with people who mock God represents joining the people who mock God. AT: "or join those who mock God" or "or mock God with others who mock him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: or sit in the assembly of mockers

contextId.information: Using one's voice to cry out is spoken as as lifting up his voice. AT: "I cry out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
David speaks of starting to do something as getting up. AT: "Take action" or "Do something" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a call for help. AT: "Listen to me as I call to you now for help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Listen to my call to you

contextId.information: Truth being in the mouth represents speaking truthfully. AT: "For they never say what is true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For there is no truth in their mouth

contextId.information: The throat represents people's speech. AT: "their speech" or "what they say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The tongue represents what people say.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
His groaning represents the pain or distress that he feels. AT: "I am very tired because of my pain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I am weary with my groaning

contextId.information: The ability to see is spoken of in terms of the eyes. AT: "My vision is blurry" or  "I cannot see clearly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The life represents the person. AT: "me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"catch up to it" or "reach it." This represents capturing him. AT: "capture me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Arising represents doing something or taking action. AT: "Do something in your anger" or "Be angry at my enemies and take action: (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
God's "name" represents his whole being. AT: "people all over the world know that you are very great" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: how magnificent is your name in all the earth

contextId.information: The hands represent what God has done. AT: "the things that you made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Remain" probably represents sitting on the throne as king. AT: "Yahweh sits on his throne forever" or "Yahweh rules forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "the world" refers to all the people in the world. AT: "He will judge all the people of the world righteously" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He will judge the world with righteousness

contextId.information: Here the words "your name" represent God. AT: "Those who know you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Getting up represents starting to do something. AT: "Do something" or "Take action" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

What people say is spoken of as being in their mouth. AT: "He always curses people and says things that are deceptive and harmful" or "He always curses people, tells lies, and threatens to harm people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: His mouth is full of cursing and deceptive, harmful words

contextId.information: Here lifting the hand to hit someone represents punishing him. AT: "Hit him hard" or "Punish the wicked person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "arm" represent power. AT: "Destroy the power of the wicked and evil man" or "Make the wicked and evil man weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Break the arm of the wicked and evil man

contextId.information: The writer is saying that he longs for God to come from Jerusalem to help Israel. AT: "I wish that Yahweh would come from Jerusalem and rescue his people!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Oh, that the salvation of Israel would come from Zion!

contextId.information: Here "tongue" represents evil speech. AT: "He does not say evil things about innocent people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He does not slander with his tongue

contextId.information: Here "the word of your lips" represents God's instruction. AT: "your instruction has caused me to avoid doing wicked things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: it is at the word of your lips that I have kept myself from the ways of the lawless

contextId.information: Here "surrounded my steps" represents how David's enemies have followed him everywhere he goes in order to capture him. AT: "My enemies have surrounded me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

To have "clean hands" means that one is innocent of wrongdoing. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:020|18:20]]: AT: "all my actions were right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "head" represents the ruler. AT: "appointed me to be the ruler over many nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: have made me the head over nations

contextId.information: These expressions taken together describe everything a person says and thinks. AT: "the things I say and the things I think about" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the words of my mouth and the thoughts of my heart

contextId.information: Here "day" stands for a longer period of time. AT: "times of trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
God's right hand represents his power to rescue the king. AT: "with his great strength he will rescue him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: with the strength of his right hand that can rescue him

contextId.information: Here "chariots" and "horses" stand for a king's army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Some trust in chariots and others in horses

contextId.information: "I will make known your name." Here "name" stands for God's character or reputation. AT: "I will talk about your character" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "the suffering" stands for the person who is suffering. AT: "has not despised or abhorred the one who is suffering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: has not despised or abhorred the suffering of the afflicted one

contextId.information: "For the kingdom belongs to Yahweh." Here "kingdom" represents God's rule as king. AT: "For Yahweh is king" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The rod and staff represent protection because shepherds use them to protect their sheep from danger. AT: "I am not afraid because you protect me like a shepherd who protects his sheep with his rod and staff" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]]
contextId.quote: your rod and your staff comfort me

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents a person's thoughts or motives. AT: "thinks good thoughts" or "does not think about doing what is wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "generation" represents people in general. AT: "The people who seek him are like this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Such is the generation of those who seek him

contextId.information: Here "eyes" represents looking. Looking to Yahweh is a way of saying he is asking Yahweh for help. AT: "I always look to Yahweh" or "I always ask Yahweh to help me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: My eyes are always on Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents a person's emotions. AT: "I feel more and more troubled" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The troubles of my heart are enlarged

contextId.information: Here "Israel" represents the people of Israel. AT: "the people of Israel ... our troubles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "eyes" represent a person's thoughts. AT: "For I always think about how faithful you are to me because of your covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For your covenant faithfulness is before my eyes

contextId.information: Here "light" represents life. AT: "Yahweh is the source of my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "day" represents a longer period of time. AT: "in the time of trouble" or "when I have troubles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This represents the writer receiving pride or honor when he defeats his enemies. It can be stated in active form. AT: "people will honor me when I win the fight against my enemies" or "God will honor me by enabling me to defeat my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: my head will be lifted up above my enemies

contextId.information: Here "voice" represents what the writers is saying. AT: "Hear me, Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The face here represents Yahweh's attention. The phrase "do not hide your face" is a way of asking God not to reject him. AT: "Do not reject me" or "Do not stop taking care of me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Do not hide your face from me

contextId.information: The phrase "his name" refers to Yahweh or his reputation. AT: "as is proper because of who he is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]]}

All occurrences of "voice" here represent Yahweh speaking. The writer is emphasizing that when Yahweh speaks, the sound is so loud it is heard over the waters, and it is so powerful it can destroy the largest trees. AT: "When Yahweh speaks, his voice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
All occurrences of "voice" here represent Yahweh speaking. AT: "When Yahweh speaks he causes lightning to flash in the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The voice of Yahweh sends out flames of fire

contextId.information: Here "voice" represents Yahweh speaking. AT: "When Yahweh speaks, the sound causes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "moment" represents a short amount of time. AT: "a short time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the body of the writer which will decay and become dust when he is dead. AT: "my decayed body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "your hand" refers to Yahweh's power. AT: "You have the power to decide my future" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My destiny is in your hand

contextId.information: These represent lying people. AT: "people who lie" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "hearts" refers to the thinking of these people. The writer speaks of Yahweh guiding the thinking of the people as if he were a potter who was shaping a bowl. AT: "guides their thinking as a potter shapes a bowl" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: shapes the hearts of them all

contextId.information: Here "eye" refers to Yahweh's attention. AT: "Yahweh's attention" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "the eyes of Yahweh" refer to his careful watching. "The righteous" is a reference to righteous people. AT: "Yahweh carefully watches over the righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]]) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
contextId.quote: The eyes of Yahweh are on the righteous

contextId.information: This refers to the writer. AT: "me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to his statements. AT: "What he says is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "arms" represent the strength of the wicked people. Breaking their arms represents taking away their power. This could be stated in active form. AT: "For Yahweh will remove the strength of the wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: For the arms of the wicked people will be broken

contextId.information: Steps represent the way a person lives. AT: "the way a man lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "bread" represents food in general. AT: begging for food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "in his heart" refers to his deepest inner being. AT: "He treasures the commands of his God in his inner being" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The law of his God is in his heart

contextId.information: Here "smell" refer to his sores having a bad smell that is associated with rotting flesh. AT: "My wounds are infected and stink as they rot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My wounds are infected and smell

contextId.information: Here "smile" is associated with being happy. AT: "so that I can be happy again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: so that I may smile again

contextId.information: Here "heart" refers to the writer's inner confidence. AT: "I am very discouraged" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The phrase "the bed of suffering" refers to when a person lies in bed because he is sick. AT: "When he is sick and in bed, Yahweh will support him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will support him on the bed of suffering

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" refers to God's power. AT: "by your power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "sword" refers to military power. AT: "by fighting with their own swords" or "by their own army's strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the words "the voice" refers to what the person says. AT: "because of what the person says who rebukes and insults me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: because of the voice of him who rebukes and insults

contextId.information: Here the word "name" refers to God, himself. To forget God is to stop worshiping him. This is something that did not happen. AT: "If we had forgotten our God" or "If we had stopped worshiping our God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: If we have forgotten the name of our God

contextId.information: Most soldiers held their swords with their right hands when they fought. Here, the phrase "right hand" refers to his ability to fight, which the writer speaks of as if it were a person who can teach the king through the experience he gains in battle. AT: "You will learn to accomplish great military feats by fighting in many battles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: your right hand will teach you fearful things

contextId.information: The word "throne" represents the kingdom and rule of the king. AT: "Your kingdom ... is forever and ever" or "You will reign ... forever and ever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Your throne ... is forever and ever

contextId.information: The words "stringed instruments" refers to the music that people make by playing the stringed instruments. AT: "the music of stringed instruments has made you glad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: stringed instruments have made you glad

contextId.information: Here the word "I" refers to the writer. The word "name" refers to the king's character and reputation. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will cause people in every generation to know about your greatness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: I will make your name to be remembered in all generations

contextId.information: The phrase "city of God" refers to Jerusalem, which the writer speaks of as a person who can be happy. AT: "make the people who live in Jerusalem happy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: make the city of God happy

contextId.information: This means that the kings of other nations assembled their armies. AT: "assembled their armies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here the word "name" represents God's character and reputation. The two phrases compare the greatness of God's reputation with how greatly people praise him. AT: "Your name is very great ... and so people throughout the world praise you greatly" or "People all throughout the world have heard of you ... so people throughout the world praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: As your name is ... so is your praise to the ends of the earth

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the writer uses the word "heavens" to refer to the angels who live there (UDB) or 2) the writer speaks of "the heavens" as if they are a person who testifies about God's righteousness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

The heart represents either 1) the person's desires or 2) the whole person. AT: "You want me to desire trustworthiness" or "you want me to be trustworthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: you desire trustworthiness in my heart

contextId.information: This phrase refers to killing another person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "refuge" represents a protector. AT: "did not make God his protector" or "did not ask God to protect him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: did not make God his refuge

contextId.information: Rising up against someone represents preparing to attack him or actually attacking him. AT: "have prepared to attack me" or "are attacking me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Giving one's ear represents listening. AT: "Listen to my prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here, "heart trembles" refers to his emotional pain and suffering. This suffering is because of fear. AT: "I am suffering because I am so afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

"Language" here represents what the people were saying to each other, and probably refers specifically to them talking about plans to do evil. Confusing it represents making the people unable to understand each other. AT: "confuse them when they speak to each other" or "confuse their plans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This represents causing people to die. AT: "will cause the wicked to die" or "will cause wicked people to die and go to the place where dead people are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: will bring the wicked down into the pit of destruction

contextId.information: Here "the light of the living" probably represents God's enabling people to live. AT: "with the life that you give" or "because you enable me to live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in the light of the living

contextId.information: Being confident is spoken of as one's heart being firm rather than shaken or easily moved. The phrase is repeated to show that he has complete confidence in God and will not change. AT: "I am completely confident in you, God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My heart is fixed, God, my heart is fixed

contextId.information: The heart refers to the people's thoughts or plans. AT: "you commit wickedness in your thoughts" or "you think about doing wicked things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you commit wickedness in your heart

contextId.information: God's being the psalmist's strength represents God protecting him. AT: "you are my strength" or "you are my protector" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The mouths and lips represent the things people say.  AT: "Because they sin by what they say" or "Because of the sinful things they say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For the sins of their mouths and the words of their lips

contextId.information: "to even the most distance places on earth." This represents all places on earth. AT: "everywhere on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to the ends of the earth

contextId.information: God's allowing Israel's enemies to break through their defenses is spoken of as God himself had done it. AT: "you have allowed our enemies to break through our defenses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you have broken through our defenses

contextId.information: Here "see" represents "experience" or "suffer." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: You have made your people see difficult things

contextId.information: Here "name" stands for God himself. AT: "I will always sing praise to you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will sing praise to your name forever

contextId.information: This refers to their speech or their words. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the supply of water in the sky that God sends to water the earth and fill the streams. AT: "you fill the streams with water" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the river of God is full of water

contextId.information: A "joyful noise to God" represents singing and shouting praises to God.  AT: "Let all the earth sing and shout joyfully to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Make a joyful noise to God, all the earth

contextId.information: This refers to God. AT: "to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here to be "struck down" refers to punishment. AT: "you punished" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hears" means to respond. AT: "Yahweh answers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Zion" refers to the people in Zion. AT: "God will save the people of Zion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Lips" is a metonym for the whole person. AT: "I will shout for joy" (see UDB)  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My lips will shout for joy

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of the people of Israel as if they were the mountains and hills on which they live. He speaks of the mountains and the hills as if they were the entire land of Israel, as if that land were a garden that produces fruit, and of peace and righteousness as if they are that fruit. AT: "May the people of the land live in peace ... may they do everything in a righteous way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: May the mountains produce peace ... may the hills produce righteousness

contextId.information: "the people who live in every nation"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "voice" is a metonym for the words people use when they speak. AT: "what your adversaries are saying"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Asaph speaks of the one who lifts up as if he were the action of lifting up. He also speaks of God giving strength and honor to a person as if God were physically lifting that person up. AT: "The one who will lift you up will not be someone who comes from the east" or "The one who will make you strong and have people honor you will not be someone who comes from the east" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: It is not from the east ... that lifting up comes

contextId.information: The "soul" is a metonym for the person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I would not allow anyone to try to comfort me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: My soul refused to be comforted

contextId.information: Open eyes is a metonym for being unable to sleep. AT: "kept me from sleeping"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "flesh," which is weak and then dies, is a metonym for human weakness and death. AT: "the Israelites were weak and would someday die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"The enemies killed many Israelite priests using swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"descendants of Joseph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "blood" is a metonym for innocent life. To shed blood is to kill innocent people. Most people saw water every day, so for blood to be as common as water, many innocent people would have to die. AT: "They have killed so many innocent people that the blood is everywhere, like water after it rains" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: They have shed their blood like water

contextId.information: The word "name" is a metonym for his reputation, for what people know about him. AT: "so that people will know about your glory" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for the sake of the glory of your name

contextId.information: This is a metonymy for "the good things for which people will praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The lid or cover of the ark of the covenant in the temple, the symbolic throne from which God ruled Israel, had gold cherubim attached to it, one on each end, facing each other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you who sit above the cherubim

contextId.information: Here "words" represents what God said. AT: "to what I said" or "to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "earth" represents the people. AT: "judge the people of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the people of Edom who lived in tents. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These all represent the people of each area or tribe. AT: "the people of Gebal, the Ammonites, the Amalekites ... the Philistines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This represents the people of Assyria. AT: "the people of Assyria" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "land" represents the nation and people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you have showed favor to your land

contextId.information: Here "day" represents a longer period of time. AT: "During my times of difficulty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: In the day of my trouble

contextId.information: Here "Rahab" is a poetic way of referring to Egypt. Both "Rahab" and "Babylon" represent the people. AT: "the people of Egypt and Babylon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

Here "eyes" represents a person's ability to see. For his eyes to grow weary from trouble is a way of saying that he his troubles cause him to cry so much that it is hard for him to see. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: My eyes grow weary from trouble

contextId.information: Here "heavens" represents those who are in heaven. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "right hand" represents power. To "raise the right hand" means that Yahweh has made his enemies strong enough to defeat God's chosen king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: raised the right hand of his enemies

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of "terror" as if it were a spirit or fierce animal that could attack at night and so terrify people. AT: "things attacking you at night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The psalmist speaks of starting to do something as getting up. If your language has a word for beginning to act, use it here.  AT: "Take action" or "Do something" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The psalmist speaks of those who judge as if they were the decisions they make. The abstract noun "judgment" can be translated with the verb "judge." AT: "judges will again judge righteously" or "judges will again make righteous decisions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "his voice" refers to paying attention to God's words. AT: "listen carefully to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "name" is a metonym for Yahweh himself. AT: "bless Yahweh" or "do what makes Yahweh happy." See how "may his glorious name be blessed" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:072:018|72:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"name" refers here to the person of God. AT: "him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "the world" is a metonym for all the people in the world. AT: "He will judge all the people of the world righteously." See how these words are translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:009:007|9:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He will judge the world with righteousness

contextId.information: This refers to the people who live in these lands. AT: "The people of Zion heard ... the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Zion heard ... the towns of Judah

contextId.information: The words "right hand" and "holy arm" refer to Yahweh's strength. Together they emphasize how great his strength is. AT: "his very great power has" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: his right hand and his holy arm have

contextId.information: Here "arm" is a metonym for power. AT: "the power that is his alone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to all the people of the earth. AT: "everyone on the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "name" is a metonym for Yahweh himself. AT: "bless Yahweh" or "do what makes Yahweh happy." See how "may his glorious name be blessed" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:072:018|72:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The phrase "your life" refers to "you," but it emphasizes that Yahweh gives blessings throughout life. AT: "He satisfies you with good things through your life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He satisfies your life with good things

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's reign as king is referred to as his "throne." AT: "Yahweh has taken his seat in the heavens where he rules as king" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh has established his throne in the heavens

contextId.information: "with all of me" or "with all my soul." This phrase means that he will praise Yahweh wholeheartedly and is used to emphasize his devotion to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the people in the nations. AT: "the people of the nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
God caused the hail, rain, and lightning to ruin the vines and trees. AT: "He caused it to destroy ... and to break" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Egypt" refers to the people who live in Egypt. AT: The people of Egypt were glad (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here the phrase "your inheritance" refers to the Isrealites, who are Yahweh's chosen people. Here "glory" means "to boast about" something; in this case they are boasting about Yahweh. AT: "boast of your greatness with your people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "his name" refers to Yahweh. AT: "for the sake of his own reputation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here God is referred to by his glory. AT: "their glorious God" or "God who is glorious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This means that Yahweh will cause this to happen, not that he will personally kill the leaders. AT: "he will cause the leaders in many countries to be killed" or "he will allow the leaders in many countries to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he will kill the leaders in many countries

contextId.information: Here the word "house" represents the family. The words "Wealth" and "riches" mean basically the same thing and indicate an abundance of wealth. AT: "His family is very wealthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: Wealth and riches are in his house

contextId.information: Here "home" refers to the children that live in a home. AT: "He gives children to the woman who had none" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He gives a home to the barren woman of the house

contextId.information: The word "Israel" represents the people of Israel. AT: "People of Israel, trust in Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "name" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "called out to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: called on the name of Yahweh

contextId.information: The word "house" refers to Yahweh's temple. AT: "in the courtyards of Yahweh's temple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in the courts of Yahweh's house

contextId.information: The word "Israel" represents the people of Israel. AT: "Let the people of Israel say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here the word "house" represents the family and descendants of a person. This phrase refers to the priests, who were descendants of Aaron. AT: "Let the descendants of Aaron say" or "Let the priests say" (See: and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Let the house of Aaron say

contextId.information: Here the word "name" represents Yahweh's power. AT: "the one who comes in the power of the Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he who comes in the name of Yahweh

contextId.information: God's "word" represents what he has said. Here it refers to what he has promised. AT: "according to your promise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"my mouth" refers to speaking about God's word. AT: "Never prevent me from speaking your truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Do not take the word of truth from my mouth

contextId.information: Here the word "name" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "I think about you, Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "heart" represents a person's will. AT: "with complete commitment" or "completely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "hearts" represents the people's wills. A person being stubborn is spoken of as if their hearts or wills were hard like a rock. AT: "They are stubborn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "mouth" represents what God says. AT: "The instructions you have spoken are" or "Your instructions are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "word" represents anything God has communicated to people. AT: "what you have said will be true forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "word" represents God's commands. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "heart" represents the writer's will. The phrase "heart is set" is an idiom. It is a way of saying the writer is determined. AT: "I am determined to obey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: My heart is set on obeying

contextId.information: Here "word" represents what God communicates to people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

"Support me by your word." Here "word" represents what God communicates to people. AT: "Give me strength as you said you would" or "Enable me to be strong as you promised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "life" represents the person. AT: "Rescue me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This expression means "look at" or "focus my attention on." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "name" refers to Yahweh himself. AT: "Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the author refers to his eyes because that is the part of the body used for seeing. AT: "I look to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the scepter of wickedness represents the rule of wicked people. AT: "Wicked people" or "Wicked rulers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The psalmist is spoken of as if he were waiting on something with expectation. AT: "I hope" or "I trust" or "I desire for something" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The heart and the eyes represent the person. AT: "I am not proud or haughty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my heart is not proud or my eyes haughty

contextId.information: The soul represents the person or his emotions. Being calm and peaceful is spoken of has having making one's soul still and quiet. AT: "I am calm and peaceful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have stilled and quieted my soul

contextId.information: This represents serving Yahweh in his temple.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Jacob" here refers to his descendants, the people of Israel. AT: "Yahweh has chosen Jacob's descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Poplar trees do not grow in Israel. "Poplars" may here stand for all the trees in Babylon. AT: "On the trees in Babylon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here remembering what the Edomites did represents punishing them for what they did. AT: "Punish the Edomites, Yahweh, for what they did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Call to mind, Yahweh, what the Edomites did

contextId.information: The heart here represents the emotions. Doing something sincerely or completely is spoken of as doing it with all one's heart. AT: "I will sincerely thank you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will give you thanks with my whole heart

contextId.information: This refers to what God has said. AT: "what you have said" or "your commands and promises" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "soul" probably refers to the psalmist's innermost ability to be certain about God's love and guidance. The translator may, however, treat "soul" here as metonymy for the psalmist's mind and heart. AT: "I know this with all my heart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My soul knows this very well

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks as if evil words were prisoners trying to escape from his mouth. AT: "please help me not to say things that are evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: place a guard over my mouth

contextId.information: The words "wicked deeds" are a metonym for the people who do the wicked deeds. AT: "I always pray that Yahweh will stop wicked people from doing evil deeds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my prayer is always against their wicked deeds

contextId.information: This is a metonym for "me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a call for help. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:005:001|5:1]]. AT: "Listen to me as I call to you now for help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The words "my prayer" are a metonym for the person who is praying. See how these words are translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:039:012|39:12]]. AT: "Listen to me as I pray to you" or "Be willing to do what I ask you to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"chased me to try to catch me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"They speak lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hand" refers to power. Translate these words as you translated them in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:144:007|144:7-8]]. AT: "from the power of foreigners" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"no one crying in pain" or "no one begging for food" or "no one calling out for justice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "name" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "Let them praise Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Let them praise the name of Yahweh

contextId.information: The word "nations" represents the people who live in those nations. AT: "people of every nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "name" is a metonym for Yahweh himself. AT: "praise him" or "tell people how great he is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The mouth is a metonym for the whole person. AT: "May they always be ready to praise God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: May the praises of God be in their mouths
